body:
The relevant leaking bit:

```
goroutine 465377 [IO wait, 309656 minutes]:

created by main.listener
	/var/tmp/portage/net-p2p/syncthing-0.14.11/work/syncthing-0.14.11/src/github.com/syncthing/syncthing/cmd/strelaysrv/listener.go:52 +0x420
```

Thanks a lot! I updated, and will let you know if I see something is wrong :-)

@AudriusButkevicius 

I have been running the version with the patch for some time, and I see a steady increase of consumed ram. I logged RES every hour for around 300 hours, and plotted a graph:
![st r](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5206045/29671731-301d3632-88e2-11e7-864d-0b58882e4e54.png)


(every data point is RES in megabytes, each hour there is a new point)
Great. Can you send a SIGQUIT and capture the stacktraces again?
Sure. I have put it again here: https://163.172.132.71/strelaysrv.log

So I can't see any go routines leaking.
There are around ~1k subscribers in the relay (allowing things to connect to) and around ~300 active sessions (where exchanges are actually happening), so perhaps the growth is just an effect of more people using your relay, or are you seeing memory growth without client growth?

Maybe we could add http/pprof to the build, if it's not already there, so we can take a memory profile.

On 24 Aug 2017, at 23:36, Audrius Butkevicius <notifications@github.com<mailto:notifications@github.com>> wrote:


So I can't see any go routines leaking.
There are around ~1k subscribers in the relay (allowing things to connect to) and around ~300 active sessions (where exchanges are actually happening), so perhaps the growth is just an effect of more people using your relay, or are you seeing memory growth without client growth?

â€”
You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub<https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/issues/4245#issuecomment-324764406>, or mute the thread<https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAHp8sdPjdpL9Iqo5TEm6XfLBoO6AnSGks5sbezjgaJpZM4ONL_a>.
If the OP can chart clients + sessions, I think that would be easier. Adding a second http server/third socket to this thing sounds a bit sad.

I did not do any analysis, only logged the consumption of ram.

Now I restarted the relay and started a script which will collects every hour `bytesProxied`, `numActiveSessions`, `numConnections`, `numPendingSessionKeys`, `numProxies`.

Expect a graph in a week or two :-)

```
while true; do 
  t=$(date +%s)
  r=$(ps u --pid $(pidof strelaysrv) | tail -1 | awk '{print($6)}')
  wget http://163.172.132.71:22070/status -O status.json > /dev/null 2>&1
  echo ${t} \
    $(jq '.uptimeSeconds' status.json) \
    ${r} \
    $(jq '.bytesProxied' status.json) \
    $(jq '.numActiveSessions' status.json) \
    $(jq '.numConnections' status.json) \
    $(jq '.numPendingSessionKeys' status.json) \
    $(jq '.numProxies' status.json)
  sleep 3600;
done
```

A graph for the first 4 days after the restart:
![st](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5206045/29874814-cab8fc56-8d8f-11e7-8909-8d6413a8d14b.png)
To be continued.
The correlation looks good to me?
yes, very good. I will keep it running for at least a couple of weeks, as intended. Probably, indeed, the RAM consumption is high just because of the number of clients served.

So as a very rough estimate we have about 100 MB / 700 connections ~= 146 KiB with 100% GC overhead => ~70-75 KiB per session. I'm guessing most of that is buffers, maybe 2 * 4 KiB goroutine stacks or so. It's possible we can reduce the buffer usage somewhat for idle connections.

Tbh, I think its fine. We could do better by not spawning stuff right left and center, but imho this is good enough. I am closing this (as I suspect I will forger in the future), as I don't think this needs actioning now, but I'd love to see more charts from OP in the future to see if the trend persits.

I'm actually going to keep this open and think a little bit about it. The resource usage above isn't insane but it's nice to keep it at a minimum so that the relay server can run "everywhere". At minimum I'd like a real memory profile of where the usage is. Maybe it's all in the TLS stack and then we're done here.
